newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICAN ROAD ACCIDENT FUND DEFICIT SOARS.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICAN ROAD ACCIDENT FUND DEFICIT SOARS.

text.p: The deficit of the beleaguered state-run road accident insurance fund had grown to six billion rand, the parliamentary public accounts committee heard on Wednesday.

Multilateral Motor Vehicle Accidents Fund (MMF) chief executive Willem Swanepoel told the committee that the fund's accumulated deficit had grown from 3.8 billion rand in 1993/94 to 4.2 billion in 1994/94 and was still growing.
In 1995/96, outstanding claims totalled 7.35 billion rand while the fund had one billion rand in assets, leaving a deficit of six billion rand.

Swanepoel said there had been a "marked increase" in the number and amounts of claims and the situation had not been helped by the fact that there had not been an increase in income received in the form of a fuel levy between 1993 and 1996.
This meant that any increase in the income of the fund hinged on the growth in the volume of fuel sold, which had averaged about five percent.
"But in the meantime the claims...increased by something like 20 percent," Swanepoel said.
The fuel levy had been increased to 10.5 cents on petrol and 6.8 cents on diesel in August, which translated into a 17 percent increase in levy income.
"Welcome as it is, it is of course totally inadequate and hardly pays for the claims that arise in a given year, let alone work off the accumulated deficit," he said.
The best way to fund the deficit would be to increase the fuel levy by 15 percent a year, which Transport Minister Mac Maharaj had said was "politically unacceptable".
The MMF had suggested in 1995 that benefits be capped to cut total payments by 41.5 percent and a 8.8 percent increase in the fuel levy over the next 10 years to fully fund total liabilities.
Since then, there had been a marked increase in the number of claims and the picture was much bleaker a year later, Swanepoel said.
